Application to other elections

Andreas Bender

2017-10-09

library(magrittr)
library(tidyr)
library(purrr)
library(dplyr)
library(coalitions)
library(ggplot2)
theme_set(theme_bw())

In this article we show how the framework of the coalitions package can be applied to other elections, using the Austrian “Nationalratswahlen” aus an example.

Getting the data

The first step as usual, is getting the data. Fortunately, neuwal.com provides survey results from different pollsters. Thus it was easy to write a function that imports data from that file:

surveys_at <- get_surveys(country="AT")

which, as for Germany (country = "DE") returns a nested tibble:

surveys_at
## # A tibble: 17 x 2
##    pollster           surveys           
##    <chr>              <list>            
##  1 "AG Wahlen"        <tibble [1 x 5]>  
##  2 AKonsult           <tibble [8 x 5]>  
##  3 "Christina Matzka" <tibble [2 x 5]>  
##  4 Gallup             <tibble [127 x 5]>
##  5 GfK                <tibble [3 x 5]>  
##  6 Hajek              <tibble [33 x 5]> 
##  7 Humaninstitut      <tibble [1 x 5]>  
##  8 IFES               <tibble [3 x 5]>  
##  9 IMAS               <tibble [26 x 5]> 
## 10 Karmasin           <tibble [30 x 5]> 
## 11 Market             <tibble [52 x 5]> 
## 12 meinungsraum.at    <tibble [12 x 5]> 
## 13 OGM                <tibble [20 x 5]> 
## 14 "Research Affairs" <tibble [26 x 5]> 
## 15 SORA               <tibble [1 x 5]>  
## 16 Spectra            <tibble [7 x 5]>  
## 17 "Unique Research"  <tibble [50 x 5]>

To obtain a pooled survey (wheited average over last 14 days, that takes correlation between different pollsters into account), you could use the pool_surveys and specify the pollsters that should be considered when pooling. However, there is also a wrapper function to do this for Austrian surveys

pooled_at <- pool_austria(surveys_at)
pooled_at
## # A tibble: 7 x 8
##   pollster date       start      end        respondents party  perc… votes
##   <chr>    <date>     <date>     <date>           <dbl> <chr>  <dbl> <dbl>
## 1 pooled   2017-10-09 2017-09-29 2017-10-06        1499 FPÖ    25.4  381  
## 2 pooled   2017-10-09 2017-09-29 2017-10-06        1499 GRÜNE   4.49  67.2
## 3 pooled   2017-10-09 2017-09-29 2017-10-06        1499 NEOS    4.69  70.3
## 4 pooled   2017-10-09 2017-09-29 2017-10-06        1499 others  2.28  34.2
## 5 pooled   2017-10-09 2017-09-29 2017-10-06        1499 ÖVP    33.7  505  
## 6 pooled   2017-10-09 2017-09-29 2017-10-06        1499 PILZ    4.56  68.3
## 7 pooled   2017-10-09 2017-09-29 2017-10-06        1499 SPÖ    24.9  372

The above steps are not necessary. To use the coalitions package, you just need a data frame (or tibble) similar to pooled_at, which doesn’t have to be a pooled survey. Given the survey, the workflw is equivalent to the one described in the workflow vignette. However, it is necessary, to take the method for seat distribution, as well as the threshold and number of seats of the specific parliament of interest into account.

## first specify coalitions of interest
coalitions=list(
      c("ÖVP", "GRÜNE", "NEOS", "PILZ"),
      c("ÖVP", "FPÖ"))
res_df <- pooled_at %>%
  collapse_parties() %>%
  mutate(draws = map(survey, draw_from_posterior, nsim=100, correction=0.005)) %>%
  ## note distrib.fun, n_seats and hurdle arguments, specified for Austria
  mutate(seats = map2(draws, survey, get_seats, distrib.fun = dHondt, n_seats = 183,
    hurdle = 0.04))  %>%
  mutate(majorities = map(seats, have_majority, coalitions=coalitions,
    seats_majority = 92)) %>%
  mutate(probabilities = map(majorities, calculate_probs,coalitions=coalitions))

res_df
## # A tibble: 1 x 10
##   polls… date       start      end        respo… survey draws  seats majo…
##   <chr>  <date>     <date>     <date>      <dbl> <list> <list> <lis> <lis>
## 1 pooled 2017-10-09 2017-09-29 2017-10-06   1499 <tibb… <tibb… <tib… <tib…
## # ... with 1 more variable: probabilities <list>

From this we can calculate properties of interest, e.g. probability that small parties will pass the 4% threshold or coalition probabilities:

## probability of passing the 4% threshold
res_df %>% pull(draws) %>% flatten_dfc() %>% apply(2, function(party) mean(party > 0.04))
##    FPÖ  GRÜNE   NEOS others    ÖVP   PILZ    SPÖ 
##   1.00   0.80   0.88   0.00   1.00   0.88   1.00
## coalition probabilities
res_df %>% pull(probabilities)
## [[1]]
## # A tibble: 2 x 2
##   coalition           probability
##   <chr>                     <dbl>
## 1 GRÜNE_NEOS_ÖVP_PILZ        6.00
## 2 FPÖ_ÖVP                  100
